content:
Since January 01,2019 the Packaging Act (VerpackG) has been in force in Germany.

Germany has set itself the following recycling targets for aluminium packaging (cf.VerpackG, §16(2))

  • 80% for aluminium packaging since 2019 (by Jan. 2022 90% of material recycling)
  • 55% for composites since 2019 (by Jan.2022 70%)
These targets are based on the current licensed quantity. Please keep this in mind when comparing targets set by the EU or specific countries.

The recyclate is only used in non-food applications.

Target applications include:

  • buckets
  • components of household appliances

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted into the following sorting fractions:

  • Film fraction for films >DIN A4 size (by wind sifter)
  • Mixed PO-flex (by wind sifter and NIR detection) in newer facilities
  • Mixed plastics (by wind sifter and NIR detection) in newer facilities, if no Mixed PO-flex available

The recyclate is only used in non-food applications.

Target applications include:

  • bottles
  • foils (e.g. garbage bags)
  • pipes

{{target_packaging_name}} is collected with all other types of lightweight packaging waste in the yellow bag or the yellow bin. In most parts of Germany, lightweight packaging waste is collected via kerbside collection. In exceptional cases, there is still a delivery scheme where consumers bring their waste to fixed container locations.
There are currently good recycling options for paper.

There exist no recycling options at scale for sorted {{target_packaging_name}}.
  • The Recycling options for Mixed PET is limited. Only bottles are recycled.
  • There are no Recycling options available for PET Trays.
  • The Recycling options for Mixed Plastics is very limited. This fraction is often used for energy recovery.

The recyclate is only used in non-food applications.

Target applications include, depending on fraction:

  • Thermoformed plates
  • Furniture feet
  • Plant trays
  • Office filing
  • Hangers

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted in the following sorting fractions:
  • PS <= 1 liter
  • Rigid plastics (PE,PP,PS)

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted into the following sorting fractions:
  • Aluminium
There is currently no recovered {{target_packaging_name}}, hence, no end market is of relevance.

Plastics containing paper are collected with all other types of lightweight packaging waste in the yellow bag or the yellow bin. In most parts of Germany, lightweight packaging waste is collected via kerbside collection. In exceptional cases, there is still a delivery scheme where consumers bring their waste to fixed container locations.
There is currently no recovered {{target_packaging_name}}, hence, no end market is of relevance.

Different recycling options exist for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • Recycling options for LDPE mono fraction exist. This fraction produces the highest quality of all fractions for films.
  • The Recycling options for Mixed PO is limited.*
  • The Recycling options for Mixed Plastics is very limited. This fraction is often used for energy recovery.
*While the recycling options are limited, MPO fractions are defined as recyclable fractions by the Minimum Standard (cf. §21 (3) VerpackG, Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister). This means that there are ways to recycle these fractions but these are not as widely implemented as for other fractions.

The number of sorting facilities for lightweight packaging accounts to approximately 25 and covers around 3 million tons of capacity.
Germany is currently importing approximately <1% of collected household packaging waste from surrounding countries.
Germany does not export unsorted household packaging.
TODO: Info Pfandsystem

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted into the following sorting fractions:

  • Mixed PO-flex (by wind sifter and NIR detection) in newer facilities
  • Mixed PO (by wind sifter and NIR detection)
  • Mixed Plastics (by wind sifter)
No separate sorting fraction exists at scale for {{target_packaging_name}}

Different recycling options exist at scale for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • Recycling options for LDPE mono fraction exist. This fraction produces the highest quality of all fractions for films.
  • The Recycling options for film fraction have a low quality. Around 70-74% of this fraction can be recycled.

The recyclate is only used in non-food applications.

Target applications include:

  • buckets
  • components of household appliances

Last update: 28.05.2020

For more insights, please follow the attached links. 

  • VerpackG (Packaging Act Germany) 
  • German minimum standard 
  • Report waste management Germany 
  • Report on Collection by German Environment Agency (2017) 
  • Recycling of packaging waste 2017 by German Environment Agency 
  • EU waste directive

Different recycling options exist at scale for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • Recycling options for PET bottles, transparent fractions exist at scale. This fraction produces the highest quality of all fractions for PET bottles (except deposit scheme).
  • Recycling options for Mixed PET fractions exist at scale. Only bottles are recycled.
For {{target_packaging_name}} collected via deposit scheme (“Pfand”) (cf. VerpackG §31) there is a seperate sorting stream. Around 95% of this fraction can be recycled.

The recyclate is only used in non-food applications.

Target applications include, depending on fraction:

  • Automotive components interior / exterior
  • Housewares
  • Buckets and tubs

When HDPE and PP are recycled together, end markets include

  • Pallets
  • Buckets and tubs
  • Floor fasteners
  • Drainage systems

Different recycling options exist at scale for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • Recycling options for PE fractions exist at scale.
  • Recycling options for Plastic hollow bodies exist at scale.
  • The Recycling options for Rigid plastics is limited.*
*While the recycling options are limited, the Rigid plastic fraction is defined as recyclable fraction by the Minimum Standard (cf. §21 (3) VerpackG, Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister). This means that there are ways to recycle these fraction but these are not as widely implemented as for other fractions.

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted in the following sorting fractions:
  • PP <= 5 liters
  • Plastic hollow bodies > 5 liters (PE,PP)
  • Rigid plastics (PE,PP,PS)

Target applications include depending on fraction:

  • detergent bottles
  • foils

Target markets for bottles collected via deposit scheme are:

  • beverage bottles
  • textiles
Sorting fractions exist for all collected {{target_packaging_name}}.

There exist no recycling options at scale for sorted {{target_packaging_name}}.
  • The Recycling options for film fraction has a low quality. Around 70-74% of this fraction can be recycled. {{target_packaging_name}} in this fraction lowers the quality of the recyclate or are sort out for energy recovery.
  • The Recycling options for Mixed Plastics is very limited. This fraction is often used for energy recovery
There is currently no recovered {{target_packaging_name}}, hence, no end market is of relevance.

The Packaging Law stipulates that consumers must be informed about the purpose of separate collection. This is supposed to provide consumers with comprehensive information on how to properly separate waste.

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted in the following sorting fractions:

  • PET bottles, transparent
  • Mixed PET

For {{target_packaging_name}} collected via deposit scheme (“Pfand”) (cf. VerpackG §31) there is a seperate sorting stream.
There is currently no recovered {{target_packaging_name}}, hence, no end market is of relevance.
For multi material Paper/Plastic there are currently limited recycling options. The plastic parts are not recovered.
Seperate sorting of PS is partially declining due to low quantities in the waste stream.
There exist no recycling options at scale for sorted {{target_packaging_name}}.
Mono paper is collected with all other paper articles in the blue / green paper bin.

The recyclate is only used in non-food applications.

Target applications include:

  • bottles
  • foils (e.g. garbage bags)
  • pipes
  • buckets
  • components of household appliances

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted in the following sorting fractions:
  • PE <= 5 liters
  • Plastic hollow bodies > 5 liters (PE,PP)
  • Rigid plastics (PE,PP,PS)

Different recycling options exist at scale for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • Recycling options for PS fraction exist at scale.
  • The Recycling options for Rigid plastics is limited.*
*While the recycling options are limited, the Rigid plastic fraction is defined as recyclable fraction by the Minimum Standard (cf. §21 (3) VerpackG, Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister). This means that there are ways to recycle these fraction but these are not as widely implemented as for other fractions.

There exist recycling options at scale for {{target_packaging_name}}.
  • Recycling options for Aluminium fraction exist. Most of this fraction is recycled via pyrolysis. Composite materials are used for energy recovery. Over 90% of the aluminium share can be recycled.
In Germany there are 2 pyrolysis facilities in operation.

There exist no recycling options at scale for sorted {{target_packaging_name}}.
  • The Recycling options for Mixed Plastics is very limited. This fraction is often used for energy recovery.

Different recycling options exist for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • The Recycling options for Mixed PO-flex is limited.*
  • The Recycling options for Mixed PO is limited.*
  • The Recycling options for Mixed Plastics is very limited. This fraction is often used for energy recovery.
*While the recycling options are limited, MPO fractions are defined as recyclable fractions by the Minimum Standard (cf. §21 (3) VerpackG, Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister). This means that there are ways to recycle these fractions but these are not as widely implemented as for other fractions.
100% of the population has access to separate collection of {{target_packaging_name}}.

Packaging distributors are obliged to participate in a dual system and must pay license fees for them. In Germany, the dual systems are organized by 9 different operators at the private sector level. It is therefore not the state, but the manufacturer of the packaging that is responsible for disposal. The "Zentrale Stelle" checks compliance with the Packaging Act. This guarantees a comprehensive and separate collection of packaging waste in Germany.
The paper is normally directly sorted in the recycling facility.

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted into the following sorting fractions:

  • Film fraction for films >DIN A4 size (by wind sifter)
  • Mixed plastics (by wind sifter and NIR detection) in newer facilities

The recyclate is only used in non-food applications.

Target applications include, depending on fraction:

  • bottles
  • pipes
  • Buckets

When HDPE and PP are recycled together, end markets include

  • Pallets
  • Buckets and tubs
  • Floor fasteners
  • Drainage systems
If paper is detected by NIR the packaging is sorted into a paper stream.

Different recycling options exist at scale for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • The Recycling options for film fraction has a low quality. Around 70-74% of this fraction can be recycled. The PP in this fraction lowers the quality of the recyclate.
  • The Recycling options for Mixed PO-flex is limited.*
  • The Recycling options for Mixed Plastics is very limited. This fraction is often used for energy recovery
*While the recycling options are limited, MPO fractions are defined as recyclable fractions by the Minimum Standard (cf. §21 (3) VerpackG, Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister). This means that there are ways to recycle these fractions but these are not as widely implemented as for other fractions.

Since January 01,2019 the Packaging Act (VerpackG) has been in force in Germany.

Germany has set itself the following recycling targets for plastic packaging (cf.VerpackG, §16(2)) 

  • 90% for plastic packaging since 2019 (at least 65%(58,5%) of material recycling since 2019, by Jan. 2022 70%(63%) of material recycling) 
  • 55% for composites since 2019 (by Jan.2022 70%)

These targets are based on the current licensed quantity. Please keep this in mind when comparing targets set by the EU or specific countries.

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted into the following sorting fractions:

  • Mixed plastics (by wind sifter)

Different recycling options exist at scale for {{target_packaging_name}} depending on the sorted fractions.
  • Recycling options for PP fractions exist at scale. Around 70% of this fraction can be recycled.
  • Recycling options for Plastic hollow bodies exist at scale.
  • The Recycling options for Rigid plastics is limited.*
*While the recycling options are limited, the Rigid plastic fraction is defined as recyclable fraction by the Minimum Standard (cf. §21 (3) VerpackG, Zentrale Stelle Verpackungsregister). This means that there are ways to recycle these fraction but these are not as widely implemented as for other fractions.
The recycled paper is used for new paper articles.
The recycled paper is used for new paper articles, mostly office supplies.

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted in the following sorting fractions:

  • Mixed PET
  • PET Trays (Minimum 70% PET Trays and 30% PET bottles transparent)
  • Mixed Plastics
The main end market is the automotive sector.

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted into the following sorting fractions:

  • LDPE mono fraction >A5 (by wind sifter and NIR detection) in newer facilities
  • Mixed PO (by wind sifter and NIR detection)
  • Mixed Plastics (by wind sifter)

{{target_packaging_name}} is mostly sorted into the following sorting fractions:

  • Film fraction for films >DIN A4 size (by wind sifter)
  • LDPE mono fraction (by wind sifter and NIR detection) in newer facilities
